results.title: London to Sydney marathon
results.creator_credit: Visnews, Graham Ashby and Tony Green
results.brief_description: Follows the 1968 London to Sydney car-racing marathon. Commentary by Raymond Baxter.

results.title: London to Brighton in four minutes
results.brief_description: By use of timelapse photography, this film gives an impression of travel by train at approximately the speed of sound. Photographed at two frames per second (instead of the normal twenty four) from the train driver’s cabin, every foot of the rail track is seen. Whereas the journey from London to Brighton takes an hour at an average speed of 65 miles per hour, this unusual journey takes four minutes at an average speed of 800 miles per hour.

results.title: London terminus
results.brief_description: From London a vast national railway system radiates: at the railway terminus in London, 1,704 trains enter and leave the station every day. Millions of urban workers depend entirely on the railway system for their daily transport to and from central London, and, in addition, there are many expresses and goods trains which span the length and breadth of Great Britain. Music composed by Horace Somerville, played by London Symphony Orchestra under Muir Mathieson.

results.title: London scene
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Frank Gardner
results.brief_description: A picture of life in London. Follows the course of a typical day: arrival of early-morning fruit and vegetables at Covent Garden; invasion of the City by a million workers from the suburbs; the parks of London, havens for office workers during lungh-time; diversity of shops and busy streets; the zoo; Crown Jewels in the Tower. After dark, the cry of “Time, gentlemen, please!” in the public hotels brings the day to a close.

results.title: London can take it!
results.creator_credit: GPO Film Unit, Harry Watt and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: London life in the blitz is presented as ‘a series of contrasts between the ordinary and the extraordinary, the casual and the tense, beauty and destruction, stillness and action, silence and noise, light and dark’. This is surrealism based not on symbolic representation of the subconscious but on images of everyday, images transformed by exceptional circumstances of war. These images are public not private. Their power is entirely cultural and social. The commentary by American correspondent Quentin Reynolds interacts in quite a complex way with the images. Primarily intended for North American audiences, a shorter five minute adaptation called Britain Can Take It was screened very successfully in British cinemas and was something of a breakthrough for British documentary.

results.title: London's water supply
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures and Metropolitan Water Board
results.brief_description: Illustrates how the Board supplies some six and a half million people in and around London with water for all their needs - a daily consumption of 380 million gallons. Shows where the water sources are, water treatment, pumping, quality control and distribution, waste detection and administration.

results.title: London's country
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson, Harold Lowenstein and Syd Sharples
results.brief_description: Presents a world of wildlife and flowers and scenic beauty - where people can enjoy yachting on the Thames, or archery at Sevenoaks; riding at Knole Park, or morris-dancing at Westerham; walking over the hills near Newlands Corner, or cricket on the green at Cookham; where they can admire historic buildings - Windsor Castle, Canterbury Cathedral, Farnham Keep, the Dickens houses at Rochester, the Roman ruins at Verulamium.

results.title: London
results.brief_description: A musical tour of London showing various historical sites and icons to a selection of tunes including “Around the Marble Arch”, “Let’s all go down The Strand”, “Old father Thames”, “London Bridge is falling down” etc.

results.title: Lolita
results.creator_credit: Lolita Productions Inc, Mario Kassar, Joel B Michaels and Adrian Lyne
results.brief_description: Following in the footsteps of Stanley Kubrick, Adrian Lyne brings to the screen the second film version of Vladimir Nabokov’s controversial 1955 novel “Lolita”. “Lolita” follows the exploits of bachelor Humbert Humbert (Jeremy Irons) who marries a jaded widow (Melanie Griffith), whom he secretly loathes, in order to get closer to his object of obsession, her teenage daughter, Lolita (Dominique Swain). Humbert’s obsession for Lolita takes them both to some dark sexual and psychological places. Following his wife’s timely death Humbert seizes the opportunity to take Lolita on a cross-country journey - one that tracks the sexual progression of the relationship between step-father and daughter. Having majored in erotic cinema in the past (Nine and a half weeks, Fatal attraction, Indecent proposal, Unfaithful) Adrian Lyne is well placed to deliver the sexual fantasies of Humbert to the big screen. Jeremy Irons is a nervous and manipulative Humbert, suffering guilt for his sexual fantasies even as he exploits Lolita in order to realise them. Dominique Swain is well cast as Lolita - the young nubile nymphette, only faintly aware of the intensity of her sexual power over the hapless Humbert. Original score by Ennio Morricone.

results.title: Lola Montes [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Gamma-Film, Ralph Baum and Max Ophuls
results.brief_description: Max Ophuls last film (and first in colour), recounts the true life adventures of Lola Montes (Martine Carol), a famous courtesan whose notorious affairs with composer Franz Litz (Will Quadflieg) and Ludwig the First, King of Bavaria (Anton Walbrook), made her the talking point of European society. Told mainly in flashback, the film begins with Lola as the main attraction in a circus where the audience pay to ask her questions about her nefarious past. Ophuls trademark roving camera and opulent set design are serviced well by the cinemascope frame, while the bold use of colour imbues the film with a vibrant dreamlike quality. However it’s the fallen Lola, her life reduced to a grand sideshow spectacle that carries the most resonance, a potent metaphor for a filmmaker whose main body of work was one grand tribute after another to passionate women ruined by love. Adapted from the novel “La vie Extraordinaire de la Lola Montes” by Cecil Saint-Laurent. Also known as ‘The Sins of Lola Montes’ or ‘The Fall of Lola Montes’. Cast also includes Peter Ustinov, Oskar Werner, Henri Guisol, Lise Delamare. In French with English subtitles. See also “Letter from an unknown woman”(1948), “La Ronde”(1950).
